Name: Olsen banden spillet: De 14 kup
Description:
Olsen Banden: De 14 Kup (The Olsen Gang: The 14 Heists) is based on a series of comedy movies about a gang of robbers who always try to score the big coup and flee to Mallorca, Spain, but in the end they (almost) always fail.

These films were from Denmark, and were a big success in Germany in the 70's and 80's as well.

This game allows you to recreate any of their 14 heists, while following the plot from the movies, allowing you to capture the atmosphere and humor from these films.

Players will move around the gameboard while visiting famous locations from the movie series, in an attempt to gather the tools to commit the heists, commit them, and ultimately escape to Mallorca with the loot.

But, beware! The other players are able to move the villains "Bøffen" (The Beef) and "Kommissæren" (The Detective) around the map, in order to stop the other player's advancement in the game.

Name: Where is Mausi?
Description:
A kids card game where Mausi the Mouse visits her friends the goose, the cow, the horse, the rabbit and the pig and hides with one of them. Players have to guess where Mausi is hanging for the day, winning the card on which she's located if they do. Be the first to reveal cards with all five friends on them and you win.

The short description: Each player has five cards depicting the animal friends, and these are shuffled and placed face-down before the player. On a turn, the player rolls the die, flips an animal card in front of her, and hopes it shows the animal on the die; if so, the card stays revealed; if not, the card is flipped face-down again. Roll an animal that's already revealed, and you can flip a card of your choice. Roll the moon, and one of the timing cards is flipped. The game ends when one player finds all five friends or time runs out, in which case no one wins.

How to play Wo Ist Mausi?:

- The six-Mausi cards with the page "Mausi comes home" to the top placed in the middle of the table. 
- Each player is dealt five cards with the same animal back color and places them with the back upwards before him. 
- Whoever's turn it is throws an animal that needs to turn one of his cards. If it is he animal rolles on the die, the card is exposed. 
- If there is a different animal, the card will once again be face down. 
-The dice shows the moon is one of the six cards on the side of Mausi, "Mausi sleeps" reversed. 
- The dice shows an animal that the player has already found, nothing happens. 
- Winner is the person who discovered the first five friends of Mausi on his maps. 
-When Erica is sleeping all six cards on the page "Mausi" lie, there is no winner.

Name: Balyna Magnetic Super Soccer
Description:
Soccer game produced by Balyna (Toogood and Jones of Whitstable in Kent) in the United Kingdom during the 1950s.

Game consists of:

- playing board
- four adjustable metal legs to be inserted at each corner of the board
- two plastic goals
- two plastic playing rods with a magnet at the end, one each of red and blue
- four plastic players with magnets on their bases, usually 2 red and 2 blue players
- a small plastic ball
- rules

Each player has a magnet on the bottom of its base, which was manipulated by a rod (with a magnet on the end of it) which went under the table. The magnets of each team are polarised in reverse, so you cannot move your opponents players with your rod. The rod is used to drag your players across the board, thus allowing you to push the ball around.

The game board is a smooth hardboard surface, marked out with a football pitch, and a basic raised surround to stop the ball going out of play.

Magnetic football is excellent fun - a splendid ice breaker at parties and games evenings - and requires a surprising amount of skill. If you move the players too fast, or use too much power, then it is very easy to leave either the player or the ball behind! Although you cannot control your opponent's players, your reversed magnet can be used to flip them over.

Name: Drake
Description:
A game from the Ahoy Series by Edmund Vale.  This is a game of Privateers vs. Spanish Galleons.  The Galleons, one carrying the Treasure, are attempting to deliver it to their home port while the Privateers are attempting to capture the gold.  All ships have equal speed, strength and vulnerability.

The game is based around the map, which shows wind direction in each diamond as well as ports, forts (gray areas with letters and gold triangles), calm areas (diamonds containing blue sea serpents), sandbars(yellow diamonds), dry land (gray diamonds), ice flows (icebergs in the diamond) and coral reefs (orange diamonds).  The ships move around the map based on the wind direction and are really only limited to changes in wind direction and decisions to change ship direction.  Chance only comes into play when you move on to a calm area, the teetotum is then used to determine whether the wind comes up.

A ship is given 6 wooden beads at the beginning of the game to represent its strength.  Loss of beads due to difficult maneuvers, combat or running aground can lead to "disablement" which takes away some of the ability to change directions during your turn.  A second disablement (loss of 4 beads) means the ship can only move 1 square a turn.

In Combat Privateers shoot on the N/S/E/W lines (diagonals) and the Galleons shoot NE/NW/SE/SW down the rows.  Each ship can fire up to 2 space away and Combat includes the concept of Leeway, drifting on the tide as combat occurs, leading to some chance as a players ship may run aground or collide with another.  Ships can be boarded and even attacked by the forts shown on the map.

This is a game of maneuver where advanced planning is key and the effects of tide and wind drive the game.

An outstanding example of Naval Miniatures play from the 1930s.

Name: Culture Shock
Description:
Game of world travel and culture for 2 to 4 players, ages 12 to adult. Be the first to travel to all 10 cultural regions of the world to win. Start on any international city. Travel your own route. Play your cards smartly. Leave your markers to block your opponents' routes.

Includes game board, 123-card deck, 4 wood player pieces, and 40 wood markers.

Name: Gospitch  & Ocaña 1809
Description:
Gospitch (May 21 & 22 1809, Dalmatia) and  Ocaña (November 19 1809, Spain) are the 27e and 28e battles of the series Jours de Gloire.

Gospitch simulates, on a battalion scale, the combat which opposed the French Army in Dalmatia, under Marshal Marmont and the Croatian troops of the Austrian army, led by colonel Rebrovik.

Ocaña simulates, on a regimental scale, the combat which opposed the French Army of king Joseph to the Spanish army under general Aréizaga .
This module also includes the combat of Ontigola, fought on November 18 by three French dragons regiments, led by general Sébastiani , against the Spanish riders of general Freire .

Name: CAP Kalle Ankas rymdspel
Description: A simple roll and move Walt Disney game, but it is rare and it is sought by collectors.Donald Duck and his nephews are travelling in space.

Name: Elementaurs Boot Camp
Description:
Players play from a hand of cards which have creatures with attributes that are based on the properties of the elements on the periodic table. Each player is trying to collect the largest army, there is no actual fighting in the base game but this is planed for adding into future expansions.
The top card of the draw pile is turned over, and each player tried to win that card to their army by playing a card from their hand that can match to that card and also using their standard multiplier cards that they can keep and reuse in the game. The winning player, which is determined by the actually chemical reactivity printed on the card, adds wining pair of cards to his army, and the loser takes the card they played back into their hand. The winner then draws back their hand to starting number and reveals the next card off the draw deck to win.
When the entire draw deck is emptied players can attempt to combine cards from their had and if that is possible can then add them to their army. The winner is the player with the largest army.

From the publisher's website:

The ELEMENTAURS were originally created as nanorobots but through a fortuitous accident in a bioreactor these synthesised beings took on a life of their own. They are living beings who have much to offer the human race. They can teach us many things, give us gifts, help us solve problems and defeat our enemies. Neither good nor bad, tame nor wild, they take on some of the personality of the human who releases them.

ELEMENTAURS BOOT CAMP is an exciting new card game with adventures on a subatomic level. In this game you meet the first eighteen of the ELEMENTAURS. You learn which clans they belong to, how they might behave and, most importantly, how to recruit them to your team.

ELEMENTAURS BOOT CAMP may be played at many different levels, depending on the age and ability of the players. From the simplest games through to the challenging COMBAT COMBOS there is something for everyone. And after the games are played, just looking at the cards is an enlightening experience. There is much to be learned and laughed about in the images and text on each of the cards as you decide which is your favourite ELEMENTAUR.

This starter deck is just the beginning as there are 92 ELEMENTAUR creatures to meet. Soon the next series of 18 will be released along with enemy, challenge and rare cards in packs of 10. There is also a series of books that will be published telling about the creation of the ELEMENTAURS and the adventures of a group of children in their quest to release them.

Name: League of Nations
Description:
In League of Nations, players are rival political parties struggling for power in post World War I Europe. By having the most political influence in a country, a player controls its government and may use its economic, diplomatic, and military resources to crush his enemies. But alas, rival factions wait in the shadows, ready to seize power. Push your citizens too far, and you might find yourself in front of a firing squad.

On each turn, a player may either 1) play an event card or 2) activate a country. Each player has a fixed set of event cards, allowing him to manipulate the geo-political landscape throughout the game in a myriad of ways. When a country is activated, the governing party can improve the economy, call for diplomatic sanctions, raise an army, engage in political maneuvering, seek international influence, and more. Rival parties have a chance to oppose every action, so unpopular actions may come with a heavy price.

After each country is activated once, the regions are scored. The game ends when every country has a representative in the League of Nations, a player reaches a certain number of victory points, or a party rules a certain number of countries.

This luckless game was inspired by eggertspiele's "not-quite-politically-correct game of tactics, agitation, and plenty of interaction," Global Powers.

Name: Ransom Trump
Description:
Ransom Trump is Decktet trick-taking game.

Before start of each hand, the players try to buy the trump suit by choosing one card and putting it face down on the table. Next the cards are revealed and the suit of the highest valued card is a trump for that hand. If several cards tie, then the suit of the second highest card is chosen as a trump. If the tie cannot be broken, the hand is played without a trump suit.

The player who won the trump leads and each player plays a card, matching the suit with the card, that was led. The highest trump wins the trick and if there are no trumps, the highest card that follows the suit wins it. The winner of the trick leads the next trick.

The aim of the game is to collect as many tricks as possible. The single hand takes no more than several minutes and the length of the whole game depends on the game end condition.

The complete rules can be found here.

Name: Name That Union
Description:
Given the names of 25 union crew members and 4 unions, the player will be able to categorize each crew member's name according to his or her union affiliation(s).

Each player must create a separate challenge sheet for every other player in the game. The player writes his or her name on each sheet as challenger, along with the name of the person being challenged.
Place a list of union members and their respective unions within easy reach, to be used as the answer key at the end of the game. Multiple copies (one per player) facilitate scoring. 
Players must Challenge other players to be scored. The player with the most points wins.

Name: Native American Rummy
Description:
The learner will be able to categorize various aspects of Native American tribal life by matching such things as people and artifacts into collections which represent four major Indian culture groups: Plains Indians, Northwest Indians, Eastern Woodland Indians, and Southwest Indians.

The game has a structure that is similar to rummy.Players gain points by matching up sets of cards that belong to a particular suit. Each player is dealt 7 cards and the rest of the cards are placed face down (pick up pile) with the top card turned up (discard pile). The person left of the dealer takes a turn first by picking up a card from the pick up pile or the discard pile and laying down any "matches" that are allowed. The player must then discard and play goes to the next person. Play continues until one of the players has laid down all of his cards and then discarded. The winner is the player with the most points.

Components:
56 cards

Name: Number Club: A Game of Place Value
Description:
The players will use the positional property of our numeration system in order to build the largest (or smallest number as a variation) three-digit number.

Object of the Game it to Build the largest 3-digit number and win all the cards (A variation could be to build the smallest 3-digit number).

Components:
36 cards

Name: Number Showdown
Description:
Given a deck of cards with integer values from 1 to 100, with each number displayed on three cards as numbers written as numerals, numbers spelled-out, and groups of base-ten blocks, the players will be able to point out the greater of the numbers shown upon any two of the cards.

The rules of this game are similar to the card game "War". 
Players turn their cards and compare the values shown on the cards. Whichever participant turned the card showing the greatest integer representation, then takes both of the cards and places them faced-up in a "win" pile next to his/her stack of faced-down cars. If the cards placed in the center of the playing surface are the same value, a showdown occurs.
Play continues until a specified time period has elapsed, or until one player has run out of cards.

Components:
300 cards

Name: Number Thief
Description:
The players will utilize problem solving strategies to formulate and adapt mathematical equations.

Gameplay is similar to rummy. 
The play continues until one of the players runs out of cards. Scoring is determined by adding up all the cards that are forming equations. Each card is awarded it's face value and mathematical symbols are valued at 10. Any players with cards in their hand must subtract those cards from their total.

Name: Nutrition Cards
Description:
The players will be able to classify nutritional information given a food label with current information about various food products.

Game is played 2 different ways: as a "War" cardgame or as a rummy.

In first game players try to collect the most number of cards. The player who has all the cards at the end of the game wins.
In Second game each player attempts to make 'books' using the cards dealt. The 'books' consist of groups representing Food Group Boxes. The first player to complete all 6 'books' or Food Group Boxes wins.

Name: O.B. Terms
Description:
The player will be able to state the definition of major terms used in obstetrics.

Gameplay:

     Each player receives seven cards dealt one at a time. The remaining cards are placed face down with one turned up.
     The cards in hand are arranged in pairs by matching the word with the definition, each having the same number.
     The word and the definition must be read before discarding cards.
     Moving counterclockwise, each player discards pairs first and acquires one additional card in one of three ways: by asking another player for a specific card; drawing an unknown card from the deck; or drawing the top card from the discard pile. A discard card must be played unless the player is going out.
     The player who goes out first wins the game.


Components:
100 cards

Name: Objective Power
Description:
The players shall be able to classify the given objective by matching the objective to its corresponding performance and content.

Players get Objective cards and try to matches those cards with Perfomance and Contents cards on the table.
Continue going through the Objective cards two at a time repeating as necessary until either no more matches are found or the solitaire is won by matching all objectives with their performance and content.

Name: One
Description:
The players will be able to put together numerous combinations of fractions that add up to "one". In the process they must be able to recognize the values of various fractions (i.e., that 1/2 is larger than 1/4), know fraction equivalents (i.e., 1/4+1/4=1/2 and that 2/4=1/2, etc.), and know the various combinations of fractions that add up to ONE.

The object of the game is to acquire the most points by collecting sets of fraction cards that add up to "one". The more cards used to add up to "one," the more the set is worth. 
The sets are awarded points as follows: one card (such as 2/2) = 1 pt., two cards=5 pts., three cards=10 pts., four cards=15 pts., five or more cards=20 pts. Points for the sets are added up, and the player with the most points is declared the winner!

Components:
52 cards

Name: Operation Rummy
Description:
The playerswill be able to organize math sentences into groups and/or sequences by arithmetic operation and/or result of the operation.

Gameplay is like rummy. Player matches the answers of the math-operations from the cards to be scored for the sets.
The first player to accumulate 50 points is the winner.

Components:
52 cards

Name: Orchestration
Description:
The players shall be able to name 16 common orchestral instruments and identify the four major instrumental groups (woodwinds, strings, percussion and horns) to which they belong. In addition, students will be able to use terminology relating to the grouping of instruments.

Gameplay is similar to Poker. Player try to group similar type of music instruments.

Components:
36 cards

Name: Clue Rummy
Description:
Clue Rummy combines elements of a Rummy card game with the classic Clue board game.

Detectives play melds and layoffs while moving around the mansion, searching for clues or even hiding clues from other detectives. At the end of each hand, bonus points are scored for detectives who can correctly identify the correct suspect and murder weapon.

Name: Vuonna 85
Description:
"A boardgame where even losing is fun!"

This is a promotional boardgame based on, and published in support of, the 2008 musical comedy of the same name, the name itself being that of one of Eppu Normaali's biggest hits originally published in - you guessed it - 1985. The other two local (but of nationwide fame) artists whose songs the musical is based on are Juice Leskinen, and the band Popeda.

The idea of the game is for each player to try and complete three random tasks around the city, collecting stuff needed to throw a bachelor party for Palle, who's getting married with Karoliina. The game is set in the city of Tampere in the year 1985, and is naturally full of references to the city, it's vibrant rock music scene, and the '80s culture in Finland in general. For example, the two special vehicles with their own playing pieces present in the game are a Datsun 100A compact car and a Solifer Suzuki moped, and one of the tasks is to get 10 kilos of black sausage (a local delicacy) while another is to obtain a portable VHS player for the party.

There are six different characters, based on the characters of the musical, with unique starting points and their own little characteristics such as the ability to call a taxi anywhere with a Mobira Cityman mobile phone, or get on/off a bus at any point in a bus-line.

The first player who succesfully completes three tasks and returns to the central market wins the game.

Name: Big House
Description: Vintage board game published in the 1950's in Belgium. The players are prisoners in the far west and their goal is to escape the Big House (the prison).

Name: Die Hochtouristen
Description: German board game from the 1900's where the player are mountain climbers. It has a roll & move system but what makes it unique is that it comes with a vertical standing board!

Name: Strategic Rallye
Description: Belgian vintage board game about a Rally with cars.

Name: The Great British Train Game
Description:
"The Great British Train Game" is a trivia-based family board game that takes players on an exciting train journey around the British Isles with questions on history, customs, sport, music, famous people, landmarks, literature and much more.But beware, players can find themselves stuck in a siding, on an unexpected detour, facing a delay on the line, or encountering a lucky change onto a fast train that will speed them on their way. And, if you hit the buffers on a question, you'll need to play one of three kinds of joker cards to get moving again.
The questions come graded in 3 levels so youngsters can pit their wits against older players. Contains over 3000 questions.

Name: TV Times television quiz game
Description: A Quiz in the form of a board game, includes Drama, soaps, sport, films, variety, and comedy TV shows of the 80's. The game was made in 1985 by MB games. A great game of nostalgia.

Name: Ruck Da House
Description:
Appearing in the pages of Britain-based G.M. Magazine (Issue 5 - Jan 1989), Ruck Da House is a game that features 2 players and a referee. One player takes the role of a family of Goblins and the other, a party of adventuring Raiders. The Raiders break into a house occupied by the Goblins in search of treasure... and mayhem quickly ensues.

The subtitle of the game is "A Light Hearted Game of Homicide for the Less Discerning Gamer," and most of the mechanics revolve around fighting and killing. The referee is needed to adjudicate the hidden movement which is most prominent in the early phases of the game. As the Raiders and Goblins search for each other, players plot their movement using a coordinate system laid out at the edges of the map.

The map comes as an insert in the magazine and the counters are to be cut out and mounted on a suitable material (such as cardstock).

If player are willing to share control of the two factions, then more than 3 players can play.

Name: 2 x 2 Napoleonics
Description:
DBA-inspired miniature rules specifically designed for use with 2mm scale Napoleonic figure blocks, to be played on a 2 foot by 2 foot (2' x 2')table. Players build up units of soldiers by expending Army Points (AP), and typically fight engagements with 40 AP of units aside. The turn sequence is the familiar structure of:

Player 1 moves
Player 1 rallies
Player 2 shoots, cavalry countercharges
Player 1 melees

Then the reverse: 
Player 2 moves
Player 2 rallies
Player 1 shoots, cavalry countercharges
Player 2 melees

Each unit represents a regiment and each player controls the equivalent of a corps of soldiers. Ground scale is 1" = 400 paces, or ¼" = 100 paces. Figures should be mounted on 1" x ½" bases, representing about 1200 men. All units move in increments of ¾" or 300 paces.

Combat is resolved by a single die roll, with a long list of possibly applicable modifiers. Results are of the variety of Disrupted, Recoil, or Destroyed.

Six-sided dice and a ruler (marked in ¾" or 300 pace increments) are required to play.

Name: Juego de Cyclismo
Description: Spanish card game about cycling where you play out action cards to trigger events

Name: Los Ciclistas
Description: Spanish cycling game produced by a designer from Valladolid

Name: Cycling Legends
Description: Italian cycling game; each player controls a team of riders. There is an individual and a team classification.

Name: Pik-Paks
Description: Family board game produced in Belgium. It's themed around super markets; a phenomena that was rising in Belgium in the era that this game was produced (the first Belgian super market opened in Ixelles in 1957). Players travel around the board buying goods whilst they visit small super market shops.

Name: Trikolos
Description:
French abstract game. The board has 6x6 tiles on them. Each tile also has three round spots; on such a spot a pawn can be placed, some of these spots are yellow, white, green or orange. Each player uses four wooden pawns to play on the board (a white or a black set). The condition to move one of the pawns to another spot is that it has to be free and a green or orange color. During a game turn a player can either exchaneg a tile on the board, move his pawn to a green or orange spot or move a tile with an opponent's pawn on, in that case that pawn has to start again in the back row.

The objective to win is to reach the last row of the opponent's side with all four pawns.

Name: Miam Miam
Description: Miam Miam was published in France. In this card game (with 53 cards) each player tries to create sandwiches (for example with ham, cheese, tomatoes, salade) and tries to do so by creating the most valuable sandwiches. There also is a joker card with mayonnaise on it.

Name: Reflex
Description: Very original Spanish board game with an airplane theme and a dexterity element. Each player has a set of jettons that they try to move to the discs on the seats of the corresponding arms. Meanwhile two airplanes are moving around above the arms. The player who first succeeds to transfer all his jettons to the correct seats is the winner of the game.

Name: Catch a Thief
Description: A crime has been committed in Catch a Thief. One player plays the thief; the other the detective. The thief moves his detective around lines across his board. The detective can not see the side of the board of the thief because this is hidden from him. The detective tries to deduct the movement of the pawn of the thief and eventually catch him to win the game.

Name: But
Description: French soccer game. Players can either play 1 Vs 1 or in two teams of two players each. The board consists of a football field with small squares on it. Each team has a set of 11 players (one set is in blue, the other in red). The players simulate a soccer match and try to score more goals as the other team.

Name: Jeu des Vedettes
Description: French board game published during the 1970's. In this game the players play an impresario who has to manage singer artists to the top of the billboard charts. Each player has to promote his star by using mediums such as radio, tv or by releasing a record or promoting them in the music scene. To do this the players can use promotion cards. The winner is the first player who can place 15 star discs on his palmares sheet. The game comes with images of real artists on the artist cards. These include the French singers from the 1960's-'70s era Johnny Halliday, Alain Barrière (who performed at the Eurovision song contest once), Thierry Le Luron, Michel Sardou & Marie Laforet.

Name: Contrat 500
Description: French game that combines some aspects of Gin Rummy (there are no cards in this game though) with Roulette. The goal is to finish 2 predetermined contracts as fast as possible. The players do this by choosing two numbers with their chits (that have also numbers on them). The moment that one of the players finishes his 2 contracts he wins the game.

Name: Loto Tirelire
Description:
French game published in the 1970's. It featured a set of 96 cards, tokens and a board with two rows with slots for 4 cards. The cards are divided in different theme sets (animals, celebrities, folklore, sports & work).

How the game works: each player receive a set of cards and each round they can either take a card from the player on their right or play a card in to one of the slots. If they can play a correct card on a slot space they may insert a token in a 'tirelire' (a little plastic box that represents a safe, every player has one). After every round the safe (which has numbers ranging from 10 to 1) moves one number down. The moment the safes are on number zero the game ends. The players open the safe and count the number of tokens in it; the player with the most tokens wins the game.

Name: KO Le Jeu de la Boxe
Description: French boxing  featuring two miniature boxing figurines in plastic. There also is a board divided in four colored squares; the board forms the boxing area. The players duel with each other with 5 action cards (that feature punches or moves). One round finishes after the players have played their 5th action card; then points are added up. After a predetermined number of rounds the game finishes and the winner is the player with the most points.

Name: Le Rami des Nombres
Description: French game from the 1970's. At the start of each game each player gets 10 markers with a number on them, the total of those numbers is 500. The players have to form combinations with these number markers, the one who can score the most points wins the game.

Name: Decrypto
Description: French game published during the 1970's. The players try to find the secret word of at least 6 letters the other player formed behind his screen by using deduction. The mechanism used here are slightly inspired and a crossover between Mastermind and Naval Battle. He who finds the secret word first wins the game.

Name: Le Jeu du Berger
Description: French game that translated in English means 'The Game of the Shepherd'. Each player starts with a set of tokens and a set of colored balls with a value varying from one to three. There are also numbered charts that range from two to eight. Each turn the players choose one of their balls and allocate them in to one of the slots in the charts. Each round a player wins he receives 1 token from the other players. The moment a player runs out of token the game is over; he who has the most tokens then wins the game.

Name: Echec et Mots
Description: French abstract board game that mixes a word game (players have to form the longest word) with chess pieces (each player has 2 horse pawns that he can move on a checkers style board). The calculation of the points is done as follows: two points per letter of the word minus the number of letters which remains. A no-claim bonus is granted as well. The player with the most points wins.

Name: La Course autour du Monde
Description: French game from the 1970's. The players travel around the world (depicted on the board) with a civilian airplane. The players can choose to start either in Paris, New York or Tokyo but they have to through each continent to obtain five different visas. To do this the players receive a set of cards at random in the beginning of the game. Each card has connections between different cities on them. Each turn a card can be played to move a pawn to another city or a card can be exchanged for another one. The player who gets the five different visas first wins the game.

Name: Un Nom pour un Autre
Description: Each turn a card is drawn indicating a name or word to be chosen from (a celebrity, a city, a river,...). Then for each letter of this word the player chooses picks another card indicating a topic (sports, science, art,...). The first player to give an answer connected with the topic wins a point. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins.

Name: Le Dernier Mot
Description: Based on a French tv show from the 1970's. The game consists of 82 tokens, each one marked with a letter and a wooden board with two rows with 10 squares (in each square a token fits). Each round a player forms two words (one on each row) ranging from 4 to 5 letters. Then the players take turns to modify the words (changing or to make it longer by adding and / or removing one or more tokens). The player that manages to make the word that can't be changed anymore wins that round. The player who scores the most points at the end of the game wins.

Name: La Course en Montagne
Description: The board consists of a three dimensional mountain with 4 sides made out of cardboard. Each player receives a colored pawn in the form of a photo camera and a mountain climber in the same color. The players have to climb to the summit of the mountain, passing animals that live on the mountain and they have to halt at each spot where there is an animal to take a photograph of them in their natural habitat. When they reach the mountain top they have to descend on the other side, the player who reaches the ground first wins the game.

Name: Le Grand Tournoi
Description: French rugby game from the 1970's. The board represents a rugby field; the player simulate a rugby match using an action card system. There are cards with mêlée, touch down, drop ball or interception amongst them to allow a variety of actions. To mark a goal you have to reach the last line of your adversary.

Name: Memoldy
Description: When a player lands with his pawn on a question square on the board he has one minute and thirty seconds to answer a question that either stimulates his short or his long term memory. If he doesn't succeed he has to return his pawn to the previous position. The game box mentions a minimum age of 60, this is a joke of course.

Name: Secouris
Description: French game subtitled 'caution is the mother of safety'. The board represents France with connections between all the major cities. Each player takes a pawn of his prefered color and places it on Paris. Each one then draws a destination card that he keeps secret. On each turn the player moves his pawn with the die and upon arriving in another city he has to answer a question that earns him a colored token; if he answers this correctly he may advance again, otherwise he passes. When a player has tokens of four different colors he has to race to his destination city. The player who reaches his destination first wins the game.

Name: La Course au Fret
Description: French game from the 1980s. Each player represents a transportation company that drives on the roads of France (depicted on the board) with their truck. At the start of the game each player chooses his truck in his preferred color. Each color is linked to a regional department and the player will start in the capital of that department (Paris, Lyon, Strasbourg, Bordeaux, Nice or Brest). Each player also receives a starting capital of 62000 French Franks. Then the players draw a card that indicated what good they have to transport, the weight and to which city. As a return they get a reward if they deliver the goods in time but the trucks can be delayed along the road and they have to stop for gas or food as well. The player with the most money at the end of the game is declared the winner.

Name: Roland Garros
Description: French game themed on the famous Roland Garros tennis tournament. The game consists of a board where the players move their pawns and six 18 piece puzzles (that form a tennis racket), one puzzle for each player. When the player's pawn lands on a space with the same color they can take a puzzle piece from the stock. If they land on a different color they have to take a trivia card and if they answer the question correctly they may also take a puzzle piece. When they land with their pawn on an exchange space they have to exchange one of their puzzle pieces with an opponents piece. The player who finishes his puzzle first wins the game.

Name: Extrem Memo
Description: Players turn over two tiles in a grid, and if the pictures match, they claim the tiles. What’s different from previous Memo editions is that each tile has two pictures on it and a player can choose to match either of the pictures in order to claim the tile. Furthermore, a player can search for a match from among the tiles already captured; even tiles held by an oponent. Whoever holds the most tiles at the end of the game wins.

Name: Mathzee
Description:
Translated from publisher website:

MathZee™ is a challenging math game for young and old. The diamond dice determine the numbers, you decide the math. But keep in mind, if all is said and done, there can be only one winner!

Additional info:

In each round one of the players throws the diamond dice. Next, all players try to make an equation with the numbers that the dice show. An incorrect equation means penalty points!
The game can be played at three different difficulty levels, making it suitable for both children and adults.

Contents:
5 diamond dice
1 hourglass
1 scoring pad

Name: Sudoku Color
Description:
Translated from publisher website:

Sudoku Color is both familiar and innovative. This unique Sudoku can be played solitaire or as a family game for up to 4 people, each with his/her own gameboard. Due to the handicap system kids could beat their parents. Furthermore each game can be played with numbers aswell as colors.

Additional info:

In the normal game, each of the players get his/her own sudoku board. A card showing an initial setup is drawn. All players start with the same setup by placing tokens (numbers or colors) on their own boards as shown on the setup card. Next, each player tries to finish his own sudoku as quickly as possible. The fastest player of the first round has to play the next round with the highest handicap, the slowest player with the lowest handicap. The different handicap levels are shown on the setup cards. Winner is the player that manages to be the first to complete his/her own sudoku board.

Then there's the Sudoku Sandokan type of play. In this variant, all players play on the same board. The goal is to get the board as full as possible. At first an initial setup is made based on what's shown on a setup card that is randomly drawn. The remaining tokens are then divided between the players. Each turn has to timed, so that each players has to place one or two of his tokens on a correct position on the board within half a minute. Failing to place a token correctly within the allotted time means that the player has to discard one of his tokens. A player scores a single point upon completing a single row, column or block. Completing two items (row+column, row+block or column+block) with a single token gives 2 points. Completing all three (row+column+block) with a single tile scores 3 points. The player with the most points wins the game

Contents:
4 boards
324 double-sided pieces with colors and numbers
50 cards with 100 startup situations (at 4 different levels)
Rules (in 6 languages)

Name: Le Havre: Le Grand Hameau
Description:
Le Grand Hameau is the first official non-promo expansion set to Le Havre. It contains 30 new Special Buildings plus 3 cards with corrections to misprints from the base game.  The deck is playable by itself (replacing the Special Building deck from the base game) or you can mix it with all the other Special Buildings.
The new buildings were designed by several BGG users and developed by Uwe Rosenberg and Grzegorz Kobiela.

Credited are Jay Volk, Darrell Perrins, Kevin Lee, Brian Cherry, Mikko Ämmälä, Anthony Snider, Eric Boivin, Ken Roberts, and Matt Tonks.

This expansion is included in the 2017 edition of Le Havre.

Name: ManVrouw
Description: The start player rolls the dice and gets a question according to color rolled on the dice. The questions are on cards and are assigned to five different colors. If answered correctly, the player gets a chip in the corresponding color and the turn goes to the next player. If answered incorrectly, the turn goes directly to the next player. Whoever gets all five colored chips wins the game.

Name: Panty Raider
Description: Panty Raider is a fast-paced, light-hearted non-collectible card game for two to six players. The objective is simple: infiltrate the girls' dorm and use the powers of stealth and sweet talk to snag yourself some underwear! The first to make off with five pairs wins the game, but the road to victory is never simple - to help pave the way, players have an assortment of Mischief cards with which to raid, barter, or simply drive their opponents up their wall. Build alliances or go it alone, deploy an assortment of random dorm junk, and prepare to go toe-to-toe with some of the most colorful coeds ever put to cardboard.

Name: 1099: Domus clari Geminiani
Description:
In 1099 started the construction of Duomo di Modena (Modena Cathedral) one of the greatest Italian example of Roman-Gothic architecture.
Strongly acclaimed by citizens the construction was initially committed to the architect Lanfranco and the sculptor Wiligelmo and to the disciples of their schools.
7 years later Saint Geminiano Memorabilia were moved from the old church to the new Cathedral, escorted by 6 miles guard and 12 cives guards to avoid thefts. In the following centuries the Cathedral construction was committed to Anselmo da Campione and his disciples.

The goal of this card game is to retrace the stages of the construction trying to be the one to best contribute.

Players will use materials deck to build up the different part of the cathedral. Between the first and second stage of construction they need also to take part in the Memorabilia movement.

This game wins an international competition held by Comune di Modena in 2008 for designing a game about Duomo di Modena construction

Name: Portals
Description: An abstract strategy game for two, the "Portals" board includes four "portal" spaces which allow pieces to transport between them in addition to their regular movement. Also included is a "portable portal" which can be moved (by a roll of a d4) which sometimes is to great advantage (sometimes not). Your objective: to annihilate your opponents "Guards" or capture the "Prince"... before they do the same to you.

Name: WTactics
Description:
A strategy card game with little to no luck. Several unique factions and a total of more than 60 unique units with their own traits & stats. Only 30 – 60 cards needed for a complete army
No random card draws

Based off of the Computer game "Battle for Wesnoth" this is a fantasy tactile warfare card game. Line up your troops and fight each other to the death! The goal of this project is that every player has access to all cards available. You will never be stuck purchasing thousands of cards to find a single creature, instead you just print your army!

This game is licensed under the GPL
In short, you may play the game, spread it and even sell it if you want to, but whatever you do you must always do it according to the GPL license(s).
All card art used is under GPL2 or higher, and so is the shield & swords logo.
Any other graphical material which does not depict a character or the sword and shield logo and which relates to the project is naturally copylefted under GPL3 and is available in it’s original format(s) from this site.

Name: Die Reise um die Welt
Description:
A roll and move game. You travel from circle 1 to the goal at number 50. A lot of exotic animals and vehicles can be seen at the gameboard.

Published in Nuremberg.

Name: Post und Reisespiel
Description: A roll and move game. You travel from number 1 to number 37 at the gameboard, with pictures of cities and postmen from the early 20th century. Published in Nuremberg.

Name: Eisenbahn-Spiel
Description: A roll and move game published in Nuremberg, where you travel from number 1 to 36 at the gameboard. Trains, wagons and people from the early 20th century are depicted.

Name: Jeu de La Laitière & du pot au lait
Description: A roll and move game from Nuremberg, Germany, but the text on the gameboard is written in French. "Jeu de La Laitère" can be translated as "The game of the milkmaid". At the gameboard you learn about milk when you travel from circle number 1 to 50.

Name: Le Champion
Description: French cycling game where players have to push a ball (Carabande style) and the position of the ball then determines the next position of the rider. The game comes with six prepainted riders and a ball for each rider in the appropriate color. This game was the inspiration for the game Bisikle that was released in 2009.

Name: Wizzle Mozart
Description: Each player has to complete a different puzzle consisting of 18 pieces. In total there are six puzzles depicting a scene of a Mozart opera (Don Giovanni, Requiem, the magical flute,...), each puzzle has a different color. In the beginning of the game all puzzle pieces are put in a bag. The players then take turns and move their pawn using a die. When a player lands his pawn on a space that corresponds to the color of his puzzle he may draw a puzzle piece from the bag, when he lands on a different space he may exchange a puzzle piece with an opponent. The player who finishes his puzzle first wins the game.

Name: Le Jeu des François et des Espagnols pour la Paix
Description:
Published* in Paris. A game about the war between France and Spain in the years 1635-1660. A gameboard with 26 oval fields.


     A later edition published 1705, after the death of Du Val.

Name: Neu erfundene Chronologische Spiel-Tafel zur Erlernung der Universal-Historia samt darzu gehörigen Reguln und deren Erklärungen
Description: A boardgame where you travel from Adam and Eve to the year 1718.

Name: Die wilden und die zahmen Tiere ein belehrendes und unterhaltendes naturhistorisches Würfelspiel
Description: [The wild and the domesticated animals...]. A game with money and two dice, perhaps published in Nurenberg. If you move to a domesticated animal you get money, but if you move to a wild animal you must pay. If you hit the elephant with 6 + 6 on dice you win.

Name: Das Stunden und halbe Stunden Uhr-Spiel zur einer Gesellschaftlichen Unterhaltung
Description: Published in Nuremberg. A game with two dice and money. Different times of the day are depicted at the gameboard.

Name: Die vier Jahreszeiten: Ein neues Gesellschaftliches Würfel- und Pfandspiel
Description: Published in Nuremberg. A game played with dice and money. With rules in German and French.

Name: Belagerungs-Spiel
Description: A wargame with dice published in Frankfurt a. M. A gameboard with three concentrical circles around a fort.

Name: Neues Frage und Antwort Spiel
Description: A game with questions on 24 cards in German, English and French.

Name: Die merkwürdigsten Männer des Jahres 1848
Description: Published in Germany. A game with 28 cards, dice and rules.

Name: Der Struwwelpeter: Unterhaltenes Gesellschafts-Spiel
Description: Published in Neu-Ruppin. A boardgame with 9 figures. You have five possibilities to hit the figures with two dice.

Name: Le Grand Voyage
Description:
French vintage game. Players travel around the world using destination cards that they draw each turn. Goal is to visit all continents and to do this quicker as the other players.

The game was loosely based on a tv show that was aired in the early '60 on French television.

Name: Saddle Up!
Description:
Game description from the publisher:

Saddle Up! is a game in which you DON'T want to make a match. Each card has four objects, and players must place cards next to each other under one condition: a matching object or color cannot touch vertically, horizontally or diagonally! The first player who can correctly place the most cards wins the round! With multiple levels of play, the game is always different.

Name: Scary Tales: Big Bad Wolf vs. Cinderella
Description:
Big Bad Wolf vs. Cinderella is the fourth title (unpublished) in the Scary Tales series of two-player games pitting common fairy tale characters against each other. Here's more about the characters in this game from the publisher:

"He'll huff and puff 'till he gets his way...and if that doesn't work, maybe his great big teeth will! The Big Bad Wolf has even convinced those boarish Little Pigs to join his malevolent side. She's and over-worked, over-stressed girl on the brink who's had it up to here, plus Cinderella has her Fairy Godmother looking over her shoulder. They're both crazy for power, but which has the strongest will and resources to rule the Land?"

The setting for Scary Tales is a kingdom in which a battle awaits as the king has died, leaving no heir. While the enchanted forest is feared and the castle is covered in dark clouds, corruption has affected the town and only those with the utmost abilities in Strength, Wisdom, Magic and Luck will be able to collect enough relics from the stories of long ago to prove themselves worthy of being the new leader. The challengers are sharp, indomitable, and devious - and with each match-up, it is uncertain who will win the crown.

Each character comes with its own unique ability which may be used once per game and a color coded set of dice. A set of power cards and fortune cards, a fairy card and a die associated with said fairy, comprise the contents of the game. To win, a player needs to obtain seven points worth of relics, and hold on to them until the beginning of their next turn.
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: Three Little Pigs

Name: Space Travel Hazards
Description:
From Rules:

The Space Travel Hazards game was developed to help reinforce knowledge of space travel and some of the potential hazards associated with space travel.

The object is to get from Earth to Mars and back along one of two pathways to accomplish a successful mission.  Along the way, teams acquire Radiation Points (RPs) that are detrimental to the mission.  Teams will also acquire Mission Points (MPs) that measure the success of the mission.  When the game is finished, plot the total Radiation Points and Mission Points on the Tally Card to see if the team had a successful mission and determine the game winner.

Components:
- copy of game procedures and rules
- copy of game board sheet
- Astronaut game pieces, 1 per team
- Chace Cards
- Tally Card
- One 6-sided die
- Pencil
- Score Chart (graph)

Name: Le Jeu du Berger
Description:
Le Jeu du Berger (which means The Game of the Shepherd) comes with two different variants the first one is possible from the age of three and is called 'Cours, petit mouton, cours!' (Run, little sheep, run!) and is 100% luck. Here the players have to throw a die and put the sheep on the free space with the same numbers as the die roll. The child who can place all his sheep the first wins.

The second version is called 'Petit mouton, rentre à la maison! (Little sheep come home!) and this one is possible for players aged four. Here all the sheep are placed on spots with a number ranging from one to six one. Now the children roll the die and they may remove a sheep every round but the sheep may only be removed if the number that the sheep is standing on is the same as the die roll. This way the game becomes a memory game. The child who obtains the most cheep wins.

Name: Roule Cocotte
Description: Roule Cocotte is a game about chickens that lay eggs. First the players set up the board by putting eggs in the spaces on the board. They can put up to six eggs in one space but there are not that much eggs so some spaces will only have one or two eggs and some up to six. Then they put the wooden chicken on top of all the eggs. Now the players run a die each turn. After each die roll they can lift a chicken and take the eggs below the chicken; but they may only take it if the roll equals the amount of eggs below that chicken.

Name: Whirly Wheelers
Description: Cycling game produced in the UK in the 1970's. What makes this game stand out is that the riders are magentic and no dice are used for movement; instead a spinning wheel is used.

Name: Corse
Description: Italian cycling game published in the 1960's. Up to five players each have a metal rider; one player acts as the bookie. Players then place wagers on the five riders who race to the finish line. The player with the most money after the agreed upon number of races is the winner.

Name: Pic-Etape
Description:
French two player game about the Tour de France. It consists of 48 tiles. 28 of them form the road, and must be played in order. The other 20 cards are landscape cards and are placed with one of their sides touching an already placed card.

The winner is the first to play the Paris card as long as he does not have any other card in his hand. Nevertheless, players take cards from the other player's hand once per turn, so the Paris card will change hands every once in a while.

Name: Word Pirates! Quick Play Edition
Description:
Quick Play Edition.  Half the time.  All the fun.

Can you get to the treasure first?  Roll the dice and spell a word to advance through the shark-infested waters.  Roll a 4-letter word to earn the eyepatch.  The first player to reach the treasure while wearing the eyepatch wins!  Roll and spell your way to victory, matey!  Arrgh!

Name: Giro d'Italia
Description: Ialian cycling game from the 1950's. Comes with a board that depicts Italy with roads between cities. The players move their riders (by roling two wooden dice) on the road. The game starts in Milan; the first one to reach Rome is declared the winner.

Name: Bible Boys Card Game
Description: Early 20th century card game with a biblical theme.

Name: Angel
Description:
Based on a tv series with the same name. The board represents different locations (the docks, police station, the apartment of Cordelia, a cemetery, ...) in Los Angeles. One player plays with the character Wolfram & Hart (the advocates of the devil). The other players play with Angel and his acolytes (Cordelia, Gunn & Wesley).

The principle of the game is to win points by fulfilling mission cards, these points are needed for the destiny track. The ultimate goal of the game is to advance the soul of Angel on the destiny track to level six (six points).
Families: TV Shows: Buffy the Vampire Slayer

Name: Taste Taiwan: Princess
Description:
"Taste Taiwan" is a series of thick postcard game relevant to culture and geography in Taiwan. The first game is "Taste Taiwan: Warrior". "Princess" is the second game of this series.

By adding "Warrior", it will become a four-players game. You need to match couples of different tribes during the game or you will get minus points. Each couple will give an additional score if you finish your mission on the map board.

Can be combined with:

    Taste Taiwan: Warrior

Name: Where is Leo?
Description:
From the box: Terry Terrier is in charge of looking after the dangerous lion, Leo. But "oh dear" - Leo has done a bunk!
Where has he gone? Terry immediately sets off to look for him. He retraces Leo’s escape route, from animal to animal asking them if they have seen the lion. But where does Leo’s track end? Who can help Terry find Leo’s hiding place?

Gameplay: The players open up the cards looking from card to card in the correct order to find the player where "Leo" has his hide-out. The fastest wins.

Name: Valdora: Sechs Sonderaufträge
Description:
The "Sechs Sonderaufträge" (Six special commissions) are part of the Abacusspiele spring catalogue 2010 and part 10 in the expansion-series "catalogue edition".

With these commissions you have the option to choose where to deliver and which craftman you take for that.

Expands:

    Valdora

Name: The Great Train Robbery Game
Description:
This is a game for 2 to 6 players on the now legendary 'Great Train Robbery'. On the 8th August, 1963 the travelling post office train was hijacked at Sears Crossing, Buckinghamshire, England. The train driver and co-driver were captured and the train driven a quarter of a mile to a bridge over the road. The mail vans were ransacked by the gang and the 110 mail bags were thrown down to a waiting lorry. The gang then went to Leatherslade Farm, their base for the share out. This was only 20 miles from the hold up.

Based on the actual events of the Great Train Robbery in 1963, this game is a realistic re-enactment of the chase making use of skill, judgement, initative and like life itself, a measure of luck.

Name: The Magic Bag
Description: A turn is comprised of rolling the dice three times in an attempt to create the patterns listed in the nine rows you set up at the beginning of the game. If you complete a row, you get to draw a coin from the bag to see which treasure you’ve won! You only need match the number on the tiles, but if any of your dice match both the suit and the number, you’ll win bonus draws from the bag. If your roll does not match anything on the board, you have the option of discarding a treasure to take another turn. If you choose not to do this, the game ends and the score is tabulated.

Name: Neu-erfundene Historisch-Chronologische Spiel-Tafel zur Erlernung der Teutschen Reichs-Historia nach der Regierungs-Folge der Römisch-Teutschen Kayser
Description:
A game with 49 circles where one can see German Royals. In the middle of the gameboard one can see Charles VI (October 1685 – 20 October 1740), who was the penultimate Habsburg sovereign of the Habsburg Empire.

Second edition published 1726.

Third edition 1727.

Name: Dominion: Alchemy
Description:
There are strange things going on in your basement laboratories. They keep calling up for more barrels of quicksilver, or bits of your hair. Well it's all in the name of progress. They're looking for a way to turn lead into gold, or at least into something better than lead. That lead had just been too good of a bargain to pass up; you didn't think, where will I put all this lead, what am I going to do with this lead anyway. Well that will all be sorted out. They're also looking for a universal solvent. If they manage that one, you will take whatever they use to hold it in and build a castle out of it. A castle that can't be dissolved! Now that's progress.

Dominion: Alchemy is an expansion, and can't be played by itself; to play with it, you need Dominion a standalone expansion to Dominion (Dominion: Intrigue), or Dominion Base Cards . Those provide the Basic cards you need to play (Treasure, Victory, and Curse cards), as well as the full rules for setup and gameplay. Dominion: Alchemy can also be combined with any other Dominion expansions you have.

Part of the Dominion series.
